Award.AwardTitle: Statistical Delay-Bounded Quality-of-Service Guarantee for Time-Sensitive Multimedia Transmissions over Cooperative Wireless Networks

Division.LongName: Div Of Electrical, Commun & Cyber Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
One of the most important services in the next-generation mobile wireless networks is to transmit real-time multimedia data, including video and audio. However, multimedia data need to be timely delivered within the required time period called delay-bound, because any received multimedia data exceeding its delay bound is considered useless and discarded. But, because of randomly time-varying wireless channels and interferences, the deterministic delay-bound requirements for high-volume multimedia wireless transmissions are practically infeasible. Thus, the statistical delay-bounded quality of service (QoS) guarantee theory is developed as an alternative solution to achieve wireless multimedia transmissions where we guarantee the delay-bound with a small violation probability. Availability of techniques capable of statistical delay-bounded QoS guarantee over cooperative wireless networks with mitigated interference would be a breakthrough in the next-generation wireless network research. The objective of this research is to conduct the basic studies on how to extend and implement the statistical delay-bounded QoS guarantee theory for supporting multimedia traffics over interference mitigated cooperative wireless networks. The engineering approach lies in the development of cross-layer optimization and cooperative distributed multi-antenna based architecture and algorithms to support the statistical delay-bounded QoS guarantee. The proposed framework will form a basis for deriving the novel cooperative effective-capacity and game theories for optimal power control over interference-mitigated cooperative wireless networks. Also, the proposed research will be well integrated with PI's educational plan in developing the new graduate/undergraduate curricula/course-labs at Texas A&M University.

While the statistical delay-bounded QoS guarantee theory has been shown to be a powerful technique and useful perform metric for supporting the time-sensitive multimedia transmissions over mobile wireless networks, how to efficiently apply and implement this technique/performance-metric through employing various emerging advanced wireless communications technologies has neither been well understood nor thoroughly studied. To overcome the above challenge, this project proposes to develop a set of cooperative-wireless networking based architectures, algorithms, and schemes through cross-layer design to support diverse statistical delay-bounded QoS and users' subjective measure of quality of experience (QoE) requirements for mobile users, while mitigating the interferences caused by coexisting links and mobile user cooperation. The proposed framework will be mainly based on the cooperative distributed multiple-input-multiple-output (MIMO) system to increase the coverage and capacity for multimedia wireless networks. But, the cooperative distributed MIMO network imposes new designing issues on the coordination, resource allocation, and diverse mobile users' delay-bounded QoS/QoE guarantees. Furthermore, due to multiple cooperative users, the transmit power is distributed over multiple transmitters at different locations. Consequently, the interfering range caused by cooperation is considerably enlarged, lowering the spatial frequency-reuse efficiency and thus decreasing wireless network?s capacity. To solve the aforementioned problems, the PI proposes the following research plans, goals, and activities: 1) Develop statistical delay-QoS/delay-QoE aware cross-layer architecture for optimal base-station selection in the cooperative distributed MIMO system; 2) Develop statistical delay-QoS/delay-QoE driven cooperative-effective-capacity and cooperative-game theories based framework for optimal power control algorithms and interference management; 3) Design interference-mitigated cooperative wireless network-coding schemes to enhance the statistical delay-QoS/delay-QoE guarantees in multi-hop Ad Hoc wireless networks; 4) Extend two-dimension to three-dimension delay-QoE characterization by taking into account the delay-bound violation and buffer-overflow probabilities; 5) Develop modeling and analysis techniques, and simulation-tools/testbeds to validate and evaluate the proposed mobile networks' architectures, theories, algorithms, and schemes.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has conducted the fundamental researches on how to extend and implement the statistical delay-bounded QoS guarantee theory for supporting multimedia traffics over interference mitigated cooperative wireless networks. The engineering approach lies in the development of cross-layer optimization and cooperative distributed multi-antenna based architecture and algorithms to support the statistical delay-bounded QoS guarantee. The proposed frameworks have form a basis for deriving the novel cooperative effective-capacity and game theories for optimal power control over interference-mitigated cooperative wireless networks. Also, the proposed research has been well integrated with PI’s educational plan in developing the new graduate/undergraduate curricula/course-labs at Texas A&M University. Under this PI's NSF AWARD (Award--1408601) supports, we've published one book chapter and totally 151 research papers including 3 IEEE Best Paper Awarded Papers, among which 27 IEEE/ACM Transactions/Journal papers are published/accepted in the IEEE/ACM top-rating journals, such as the IEEE Journal on Selected Areas in Communications (JSAC), IEEE Transactions on Wireless Communications, IEEE Transactions on Vehicular Technology, IEEE Transactions on Mobile Computing, IEEE Transactions on Cloud Computing, IEEE Transactions on Network Science and Engineering, IEEE Transactions on Big Data, IEEE Wireless Communications Letters, IEEE Communications Magazines, IEEE Wireless Communications Magazines, and IEEE Network Magazine, etc., and 124 papers are published in the rigorously peer-reviewed Conferences/Symposia papers, such as the IEEE leading conferences -- IEEE INFOCOM, IEEE ICDCS, IEEE ISIT, IEEE GLOBECOM, IEEE ICC, IEEE SPAWC, IEEE CISS, IEEE WCNC, ACM WUWNET, etc. conferences. The PI of this NSF Award (Award--1408601) has also been invited to present keynotes at IEEE ICCSN 2020 and IEEE INFOCOM 2018 - KCN, tutorials at IEEE ICC 2020, IEEE GLOBECOM2019, IEEE Conference on Network Function Virtualization and Software Defined Networks (NFV-SDN) 2019, IEEE GLOBECOM 2016, IEEE MILCOM 2015, IEEEWCNC 2015, IEEE VTC 2015-Fall, research seminars at the US leading universities (e.g., Georgia Tech, etc.) and top industrial research laboratories (e.g., Bell Labs, etc.). Our research papers are completed through mathematic modeling, numerical solutions, and simulations/experiments.

We have proposed a wide spectrum of schemes for statistical delay-bounded QoS guarantee over multimedia wireless networking and communications, including the followings:

1)     We have developed the wireless resource allocation policies for statistical quality-of-service (QoS) provisioning in multimedia services, including transmit power and spectrum bandwidth allocations, over mobile wireless networks supporting multimedia services.

2)     We have applied the effective capacity theory on time-sensitive multimedia wireless networks the advanced wireless communications techniques such as multiple-input and multiple-output (MIMO), Orthogonal frequency-division multiplexing (OFDM), Generalized Frequency Division Multiplexing (GFDM), and device-to-device (D2D), etc.

3)     We have applied the effective capacity theory on the promising candidate techniques of the fifth generation (5G) mobile wireless networks including: full-duplex (FD), information-centric networks (ICN), network functions virtualization (NFV), and software defined networks (SDN), etc., in supporting the time-sensitive multimedia transmissions.

4)     We applied the game theory in multimedia mobile wireless networks to investigate the mobile users’ interactions when they request for the costly wireless resources. We proposed the wireless resources bidding schemes to maximize the users’ utilities while guaranteeing their statistical QoS requirements.

5)     We have accomplished the application of the mobile data caching and offloading in our multimedia transmission to reduce the amount of data being carried on the cellular bands, freeing the bandwidth for other mobile users.

6)     We have accomplished the development of the cognitive radio networks (CRN) schemes to improve the spectrum efficiency for the multimedia data communication.

7)     We have applyed the big-data aware collaborative caching and offloading schemes for statistical delay-bounded QoS based multimedia data transmissions to develop the random matrix theory based big data architecture, reducing the extensive burden of the backhaul links and freeing the bandwidth for other mobile users.

8)     We have exploited the cooperative games among mobile users to learn from the historical behaviors of the mobile users and design the efficient multimedia offloading strategy over a group of collaborative agents. In the cooperative multi-agent games, all the agents share the same goal and learn collaboratively to make local decisions for scheduling the mobile users in the service area while maintaining a good quality of service.

9)     We have further developed the energy harvesting based green wireless networks schemes for statistical QoS provisioning in supporting the mobile wireless multimedia services, including energy-efficiency improvements and energy harvesting techniques.

10)  We have proposed the promising techniques cell-free (CF) massive multi-input multi-output (m-MIMO), millimeter wave (mm wave), massive ultra-reliable and low-latency communications  (mURLLC) for statistical delay-bounded provisioning in the sixth generation (6G) mobile wireless networks.

11)  According to our plans, we have attended the Smart Grid Research Club weekly meeting in our department to learn their analysis methodology about improving the power efficiency for both wireline and wireless networks. Also, we have collaborated with the faculty members from Princeton University, Department of Electrical Engineering to further exchange our research ideas and experiences.
